Award.AwardTitle: A Study of How Philosophy Research and Practice Can Better Contribute to STEM Research and to Public Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to develop an account of how philosophy research and practice can better contribute to STEM research and to public policy. During the 20th century, philosophy became a rigorous academic discipline, but often at the expense of engagement with non-philosophical audiences. One development that sought to remedy this situation was applied philosophy, which attempts to bring philosophical thinking to bear on real-world problems. It often focuses on issues of science, technology, and society. One example is bioethics, which developed as a new approach to philosophy characterized by direct engagement with non-disciplinary peers including physicians, patients, lawyers, engineers, and scientists as they confront policy problems. More recently, other efforts at policy-relevant philosophy have emerged, including feminism, environmental justice, experimental philosophy, and public philosophy. Such efforts face a common challenge: engaging with non-philosophers while maintaining sufficient interesting for philosophers in general.

This project will develop new insights for applied philosophy by drawing from theoretical accounts and case studies, as well as the history of institutional attempts, to extract lessons for how to better integrate philosophic insights with the demands of policy professionals. It will better organize our understanding of policy-relevant philosophical practice in order to open new research avenues for philosophers both in terms of practical opportunities and theoretical questions. The research will also help both the STEM disciplines and policy makers make better use of philosophic insights. Cultivating a new generation of policy-relevant philosophers has the potential of significantly improving policy and discussion about science and technology across multiple sectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research into the usefulness of applied philosophy is of central importance to four communities: STEM researchers, policy professionals, academic philosophers, and funding agencies. For STEM researchers, ethics and values issues, often falling under the heading of 'broader impacts', continue to grow in significance. For policy makers, it is vital that they are able to integrate elements of societal value into economic and scientific analyses for better decision-making. For academic philosophers, it is crucial to be better able to demonstrate the practical relevance of philosophic research to society. Finally, for funding agencies it is important to see positive results from their support.

A review of nine journals and some 7500 articles revealed a significant gap in the applied philosophy literature: philosophers doing socially relevant research have rarely considered the broader impact of their work. There is very little literature on either a) instances of success (or failure) in bringing philosophic insights to non-philosophic audiences, or b) the identification of tools, methods or best practices developed by the academic philosophic community to facilitate the transfer of useful philosophical insights to the STEM and policy communities. This is problematic, because absent a systematic account of how to conduct socially relevant research, lessons learned and chances for improvements will be lost.

Outcomes from our research include four published articles, an article under peer review, and a book, Socrates Tenured, that has been accepted and will be published in 2016 by Rowman and Littlefield Press. Other outcomes include six conference presentations and a project website, philosophyimpact.org. Ongoing work seeks to expand our literature review and codify our findings into a set of best practices that can be used to help shape the next generation of socially relevant philosophical research.

Our research has generated novel accounts for improved interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary collaboration between philosophy, the STEM disciplines, policy makers, and society. And it has developed a richer account of philosophical impact, excellence, rigor, accountability, and education.

This research will help both the STEM disciplines and policy makers make better use of philosophic insights. It has the potential to be transformative, in that it could lead to advances in the effectiveness of philosophers communicating with non-philosophers. This is an increasingly important goal, given the greater focus on accountability in public funding. Thus knowledge generated here can help funding agencies justify and demonstrate the value of investments in philosophical research. Cultivating a new generation of policy-relevant philosophers has the potential of improving policy and discussion about science and technology across multiple sectors. It also could open new research and employment avenues for philosophers both in terms of practical opportunities and theoretical questions.
